citations.query: Hispanics personal financial situation expect future to get a lot worse percentage
citations.raw_result:
Among Hispanics, only a small percentage expect their family’s financial situation to get a lot worse in the coming year. According to the 2015 Pew Research Center National Survey of Latinos, just 3% of Latinos said they expect their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” in the next 12 months. This represents a significant decline from 2008, when 16% expressed this pessimistic view, and from 2011, when it was 21%. The overall trend indicates a sharp reduction in pessimism about future financial conditions, with most Hispanics now expressing optimism or neutrality about their economic outlook.

Additionally, the data show that among those who rate their current financial situation as “excellent,” no respondents expected their finances to get “a lot worse,” reinforcing the strong correlation between current financial well-being and future expectations.

### References

The data also show that among those who rated their current financial situation as 'excellent,' none expected their finances to get a lot worse, indicating a strong correlation between current financial well-being and future expectations.

The data show that among those who rate their current financial situation as “excellent,” no respondents expected their finances to get “a lot worse.”

citations.query: Hispanics current financial situation categories percentage expect future to get a lot worse Pew Research Center
citations.raw_result:
According to the Pew Research Center’s 2015 National Survey of Latinos, only a small minority of Hispanics expect their family’s financial situation to get worse in the coming year. Specifically, just 3% of Hispanics believe their finances will get “a lot worse,” and an additional 7% expect them to get “a little worse.” This means that only 10% of Hispanics anticipate any decline in their financial situation over the next 12 months.

Importantly, among those who rate their current financial situation as “excellent,” none reported expecting their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” in the future. This highlights a strong correlation between current financial perceptions and future expectations: those who feel financially secure are far less likely to anticipate deterioration.

The survey also found that pessimism about future finances has declined significantly since the Great Recession. In 2008, 16% of Hispanics expected their finances to get worse, rising to 21% in 2011. By 2015, that share had dropped to just 10%, reflecting a substantial improvement in economic sentiment.

According to the 2015 Pew Research Center National Survey of Latinos, only a small minority of Hispanic adults expected their family’s financial situation to worsen in the coming year. Specifically, 3% of Latinos said they expected their finances to get “a lot worse,” and 7% said they expected them to get “a little worse.” Combined, these two categories account for 10% of respondents who anticipated a decline in their financial situation. This represents a significant decline from 2008, when 16% of Latinos expressed pessimism about their future finances (with 9% expecting “a lot worse” and 7% expecting “a little worse”), indicating a marked improvement in economic optimism over the period.

The survey also notes that among those who rated their current finances as “excellent,” none expected their family’s finances to get “a lot worse,” reinforcing the strong correlation between current financial perception and future expectations.

citations.query: Pew Research Center 2015 National Survey of Latinos four current financial situation categories percentages expecting future to get a lot worse detailed breakdown
citations.raw_result:
According to the 2015 Pew Research Center National Survey of Latinos, respondents were asked to evaluate their current personal financial situation and their expectations for their family’s financial situation in the coming year. Regarding current financial conditions, the survey categorized responses into four levels: “excellent,” “good,” “only fair,” and “poor.” Specifically, 8% of Latinos rated their personal financial situation as “excellent,” 33% as “good,” 47% as “only fair,” and 12% as “poor.”

In terms of future expectations, the survey asked respondents how they anticipated their family’s finances would change over the next 12 months. Among those who rated their current finances as “excellent,” none reported expecting their family’s finances to get “a lot worse.” This is explicitly noted in the survey’s methodology and visual data, which state that “no respondents who reported excellent financial condition said they expect their family’s finances to get a lot worse.” For those in other categories, pessimistic expectations were minimal: only 3% of all Latinos expected their finances to get “a lot worse,” and an additional 7% expected them to get “a little worse.” Combined, only 10% of Latinos anticipated a decline in their family’s financial situation over the next year.

The data further indicate that financial optimism was strongly tied to current perceptions: those who viewed their finances as “excellent” or “good” were far more likely to expect improvement, while those rating their situation as “only fair” or “poor” were significantly less optimistic. However, even among those with less favorable current conditions, expectations of major financial deterioration remained very low.

### References

- [1] PH_2016.06.08_Economy-Final.pdf
citations.content: The 2015 Pew Research Center National Survey of Latinos found that 8% of respondents rated their current financial situation as “excellent,” 33% as “good,” 47% as “only fair,” and 12% as “poor.” Only 3% expected their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” in the coming year, with no respondents who rated their current situation as “excellent” anticipating such a decline. Among all respondents, just 10% expected any decline (“a lot worse” or “a little worse”), reflecting widespread financial optimism. No image was generated or provided in the output, so no image interpretation is applicable.

citations.query: Pew Research Center 2015 National Survey of Latinos breakdown of percentage expecting future financial situation to get a lot worse by current financial situation category excellent good only fair poor
citations.raw_result:
According to the Pew Research Center’s 2015 National Survey of Latinos, respondents’ expectations about their family’s future financial situation are closely tied to their current self-assessed financial condition. Among those who rated their current finances as “excellent” or “good,” virtually no one expected their finances to get “a lot worse.” Specifically, the data indicate that no respondents who reported their financial condition as “excellent” expected their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” in the coming year.

For those in other financial categories:

- Among those who rated their current finances as “only fair,” 3% expected their family’s finances to get “a lot worse.”
- Among those who rated their current finances as “poor,” 3% also expected their family’s finances to get “a lot worse.”

Overall, only 3% of all Latinos surveyed said they expected their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” in the next year, with this small share distributed across those in “only fair” and “poor” financial situations. In contrast, those in “excellent” or “good” financial standing were overwhelmingly optimistic, with nearly all expressing either “a lot” or “some” improvement ahead.

This pattern underscores a strong correlation between current financial perceptions and future expectations: those with more positive current assessments are far less likely to anticipate significant financial decline.

### References

- [1] PH_2016.06.08_Economy-Final.pdf

The data reveal a strong correlation between current financial self-assessment and future expectations, with optimism prevailing among those in better financial standing. citations.query: Pew Research Center 2015 National Survey of Latinos percentage expecting future financial situation to get a lot worse by each current category: excellent, good, only fair, poor
citations.raw_result:
According to the 2015 Pew Research Center National Survey of Latinos, very few respondents expected their family’s financial situation to get “a lot worse” in the coming year, regardless of their current financial condition. The data indicate that among those who rated their current finances as “excellent,” **none** reported expecting their finances to get “a lot worse.” This is explicitly noted in the survey’s visual and textual documentation, which states: “No respondents who reported excellent financial condition said they expect their family’s finances to get a lot worse.”

For those in other current financial categories, the percentages expecting their finances to get “a lot worse” were as follows:

- Among those who rated their current finances as “good”: The data do not specify a separate percentage for “a lot worse” for this subgroup, but overall, the share of all Latinos expecting finances to get “a lot worse” was **3%**.
- Among those who rated their current finances as “only fair”: The combined percentage expecting finances to get “a lot worse” or “a little worse” was **21%** (3% “a lot worse” + 18% “a little worse”), though the exact share for “a lot worse” alone is not broken out for this subgroup.
- Among those who rated their current finances as “poor”: The share expecting finances to get “a lot worse” was **3%**, consistent with the overall figure.

It is important to note that the survey aggregated responses for “a lot worse” across all groups, reporting that only **3% of all Latinos** expected their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” in the next year — a figure that remained low even among those in poorer financial standing. The data also show that pessimism was significantly lower than optimism, with 81% of Latinos expecting improvement (“a lot” or “some”) in their family’s financial situation.

The survey’s methodology and visualizations confirm that responses of “a lot worse” were minimal across all current financial categories, with the most significant drop in pessimism occurring since 2008.

### References

- [1] PH_2016.06.08_Economy-Final.pdf

Data for “good” and “only fair” categories did not provide isolated percentages for “a lot worse,” though combined “a lot worse” and “a little worse” responses totaled 21% for “only fair.” No image was generated or referenced in the result.

citations.query: Pew Research Center 2015 National Survey of Latinos breakdown of percentages of Hispanics expecting future financial situation to get 'a lot worse' by current financial situation category (excellent, good, fair, poor)
citations.raw_result:
According to the 2015 National Survey of Latinos conducted by Pew Research Center, there is no data indicating that any respondents who rated their current financial situation as “excellent” expected their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” in the coming year. This is explicitly noted in the survey’s accompanying chart, which states: “No respondents who reported excellent financial condition said they expect their family’s finances to get a lot worse.”

For other current financial condition categories, the percentages of Hispanics expecting their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” are not directly broken out in the provided data. However, the survey does report that overall, only 3% of all Latinos expected their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” in the coming year, and an additional 7% expected them to get “a little worse,” totaling a pessimistic outlook of 10% across the entire group. These pessimistic expectations were significantly lower than in previous years (e.g., 21% in 2011), reflecting a broad shift toward optimism.

While the data does not specify the exact distribution of “a lot worse” expectations by each current financial category (excellent, good, only fair, poor), the chart titled “Future financial expectations among Hispanics shaped by current personal financial situation” implies that those with poorer current financial conditions were more likely to express pessimism. However, the specific percentage of respondents in the “only fair” or “poor” categories who expected a “a lot worse” outcome is not quantified in the available context.

The survey emphasizes that financial expectations are strongly tied to current conditions: those with “excellent or good” finances were far more optimistic, with 89% expecting improvement (“a lot” or “some”), while those with “poor” finances had a 49% expectation of improvement, suggesting the remaining 51% were either neutral or pessimistic — though the exact split between “a little worse” and “a lot worse” is not provided for each subgroup.

Thus, while the overall figure for expecting finances to get “a lot worse” is 3%, the breakdown by current financial condition category is not fully detailed in the available documentation, with the only explicit exclusion being that no “excellent” respondents selected this option.

### References

- [1] PH_2016.06.08_Economy-Final.pdf
citations.content: The 2015 Pew Research Center National Survey of Latinos found that no respondents with an “excellent” current financial situation expected their finances to get “a lot worse” in the coming year. Overall, only 3% of all Latinos expressed this extreme pessimism, with an additional 7% expecting a “little worse” outcome, totaling 10% pessimistic outlooks—down from 21% in 2011. While the data confirms a strong correlation between current financial status and future expectations—those with “poor” finances showed higher pessimism—the exact percentages for “good,” “fair,” and “poor” categories are not quantified in the provided results. An accompanying chart, titled “Future financial expectations among Hispanics shaped by current personal financial situation,” visually illustrates this gradient: it shows a clear upward trend in “a lot worse” expectations as current financial status declines from “excellent” to “poor,” with the “excellent” category at 0% and the “poor” category at the highest (though unnumbered) level, implying that financial hardship strongly predicts extreme pessimism.

citations.raw_result:
According to the 2015 National Survey of Latinos conducted by the Pew Research Center, the share of Hispanics who expect their family’s financial situation to get “a lot worse” in the coming year is very low across all current financial situation categories. Specifically:

- Among those who rate their current financial situation as “excellent” or “good,” **no respondents** reported expecting their finances to get “a lot worse.”  
- Among those who describe their current finances as “only fair,” **3%** expect their family’s finances to get “a lot worse.”  
- Among those who rate their current finances as “poor,” **3%** also expect their family’s finances to get “a lot worse.”  

Overall, only **3%** of all Latinos expect their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” in the next year, with the vast majority of respondents—regardless of current financial standing—expressing optimism or neutrality about future financial prospects. The data indicate that negative expectations are minimal and concentrated in small percentages among those with less favorable current financial assessments.

citations.query: Pew Research Center 2015 National Survey of Latinos breakdown of percentages of Hispanics expecting future financial situation to get 'a lot worse' by current financial situation category (good, fair, poor), excluding 'excellent' which is known to be 0%
citations.raw_result:
The 2015 National Survey of Latinos by Pew Research Center does not report any significant percentage of Hispanics expecting their family’s financial situation to get “a lot worse” in the coming year, regardless of their current financial condition. According to the survey findings, only 3% of all Hispanics expected their family’s finances to get “a lot worse” in the next year, and this figure is not broken down by current financial condition category (good, fair, or poor) in the provided data.

Moreover, the survey explicitly notes that no respondents who rated their current financial situation as “excellent” expected their finances to get “a lot worse,” and this pattern of near-zero pessimism extends across other categories. For those in “only fair” or “poor” financial conditions, the survey emphasizes optimism: while 17% of those in “only fair” condition and 15% of those in “poor” condition expected a “major improvement” (“a lot”), the share expecting a “lot worse” outcome remains negligible and is not separately quantified by category.

The data from the 2015 survey consistently show that pessimistic expectations (“a lot worse”) were minimal overall (3%), and no subgroup-specific breakdowns for “a lot worse” expectations by current financial condition (good, fair, poor) are provided — suggesting either the numbers were too small to report meaningfully or were effectively zero across all categories.

Thus, while the survey details expectations of improvement (“a lot” or “some”) by current financial condition, it does not provide a breakdown of percentages for those expecting their finances to get “a lot worse” by category, and the overall figure for “a lot worse” was only 3%, with no indication that this was concentrated in any specific financial condition group.
